wordPressPost.title: How to use “Glutathione”_ The Major Antioxidant
wordPressPost.content:
What is glutathione and how it is used in the body?

Glutathione is a powerful antioxidant responsible for the elimination of harmful toxic substances. In daily nutrition, the human body absorbs harmful toxins from food and our environment.

Usually, we do not know what happens because we do not see the harmful effects of toxins. For example, we can ingest pesticides, a harmful poison; when we consume vegetables and fruits that are not organic. Because these toxins are invisible, it is almost impossible to prevent them.

It is known to naturally occur in the human body. In contact with harmful toxins, these become soluble; and are then easily expelled from the body by urinating. It is a very potent antioxidant that doctors use to treat various diseases related to harmful toxins. Consuming a Glutathione supplement helps strengthen the immune system and improve overall health.

But the problem with glutathione is that it gets depleted with age. The older a person, the less glutathione’s in the body. The aging process of the individual also weakens the body’s natural defenses.

When taking glutathione supplements, remember that glutathione can only be produced in cells. Therefore, the precursors of glutathione must be present in the dietary supplements.

These amino acids (precursors) are:

  • glycine,
  • glutamate,
  • and cystine.

The reduced form of glutathione is known as L-glutathione. This is the label you should look for if you want to buy such supplements.

Glutathione miraculously performs the following metabolic functions:

  • Improved immune response;
  • Elimination of toxins and carcinogens;
  • Antioxidant cell protection;
  • Radiation protection;
  • DNA synthesis and repair;
  • Amino acid transport;
  • Activation and regulation of enzymes;
  • and Synthesis of proteins, prostaglandins, and leukotrienes.

Glutathione plays three main roles in the body:

Antioxidants:

The efficacy of known antioxidants such as vitamin C, vitamin E, lipoic acid and selenium are all dependent on the presence of glutathione. All of these antioxidants are at the center of the stage synchronized with glutathione. In the end, glutathione neutralizes free radicals and allows the recycling of other antioxidants in the body.

Detoxifying:

Glutathione counteracts potential toxic substances from the body including:

  • pollutants,
  • heavy metals, mercury and lead,
  • carcinogens,
  • radiation damage,
  • and drug metabolites.

The liver contains the highest concentration of glutathione, which is the body’s main detoxification organ.

Different researches carried out have shown that the content of glutathione was not sufficiently hepatic. When the liver suffers, the whole body is burdened with an increase in the toxin load.

Strengthening the immune system:

Glutathione plays a central role in the proper functioning of our immune cells, especially in the production of white blood cells. The immune system uses different immune cells to fight pathogens and other threats.

The growth and activity of these cells depend on the availability of glutathione. If your body has reached adequate levels of glutathione, it has been treated better.

The benefits of glutathione for overall health.

  • Boosts Immune Function

Glutathione is for a good reason called the “major” antioxidant. This natural compound improves the body’s function; its natural defenses and strengthens the immune function. In addition, it activates human T cells, which form the heart of adaptive immunity.

A weak immune system carries the risk of infection and disease. Your body will be less effective in dealing with stress and pathogens. That’s why it’s important to include more antioxidants in your diet.

  • Combat oxidative stress

Chemicals in the air, water, food, and household products accumulate in your body over the years. These substances produce free radicals that accelerate aging and damage the cells.

In the long term, oxidative damage can lead to cancer, heart disease, and other life-threatening illnesses. Glutathione increases the level of antioxidants in your body that protect against oxidative stress.

  • Improves insulin response

With increasing age the glutathione level decreases. This carries a risk of insulin resistance, weight gain, and diabetes. Researchers have linked glutathione deficiency to higher levels of fat storage and reduced burns. The increase in weight contributes significantly to insulin resistance.

Therefore, maintaining your high level of glutathione is important for your metabolism to function at its peak.

  • Increases your energy level

Toxins deprive your energy and weaken the function of the organs. If your body is sick or loaded with toxins, it may not work properly. Glutathione eliminates free radicals and helps eliminate metabolic waste. This leads to more energy and endurance.

  • Slows down aging

Due to its strong antioxidant effect, glutathione can slow down the aging process; and restore your youthful appearance. In addition, it has been shown to prevent age-related conditions; such as osteoporosis and cognitive decline in women.

The glutathione level drops during menopause. Which contributes to the dramatic aging of most women in this phase of life.

Oral glutathione preparations and intravenous therapy can make a difference.

These Substances Enhance the Function of Glutathione

  • Glutamine

The glutamic acid extracted from glutamine chemicals within the liver is a part of the glutathione molecule.

  • S-Adenosylmethionine

(SAM) is indispensable for the endogenous production of Glutathione.

  • Magnesium

Helps facilitate the endogenous synthesis of glutathione. Therefore, a low level of magnesium has shown a decreased level of glutathione.

  • Vitamin C

Help sustain the glutathione level in the body.

  • Whey Protein

Studies reveal that undenatured whey protein can increase the endogenous level of glutathione in the body.

  • Silymarin

Research shows that silymarin in milk thistle can help with the depletion of Glutathione in the Liver. It can increase Liver Glutathione levels by up to 35%.

Dietary source of glutathione

  • apple
  • grapefruit
  • avocado
  • carrot
  • spinach
  • and purslane

However, cooking can destroy all glutathione in the foods.

Interference with Glutathione

  • Alcohol and recreational drugs can cause depletion of glutathione levels in the body.
  • Excessive consumption of rancid fats suppresses glutahione production.
  • Hydrogen sulfide is a y product of detrimental bacteria in the digestive tract. it is present in individuals with SIBO, leaky gut syndrome and so on. It can lead to the destruction of glutathione.
  • The presence of H. pylori; the bacteria that causes gastric ulcers can deplete glutathione levels in the body.
  • Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) cause a decrease of Glutathione

How to know that a glutathione supplement is the good one.

The use of a glutathione supplement is good for maintaining intracellular health. Diets in most parts of the world are usually unbalanced. This was attributed to the deterioration of soil quality and farming methods, as well as pollution.

Nutritionists recommend eight servings of fruits and vegetables per day.  To help maintaining the antioxidants necessary for proper cell function. This situation is largely unattainable and exacerbated by the current economic downturn.

The lifestyle itself can be the main reason why most people do not eat well.

What type of glutathione supplement is the most effective?

The general consensus is that precursors of glutathione and intravenous glutathione should more effectively improve glutathione levels in the body. People who want to take glutathione should avoid oral supplements and buy precursors.

Oral supplements can be effective; but research has shown that side effects usually occur when the body gets its needs in unnatural shape. When the body produces its own glutathione, it is less likely to be shed by the cells; than when administered as an oral supplement.

Therefore, supplementing with Cysteine or (N-Acetyl Cysteine) and Glutamine is the most effective way to introduce Glutathione into the body. These nutrients contribute to the endogenous production of Glutathione within the Liver.

More Health Benefits:

“NAC supplementation can also help “pre-tox” your body when taken before alcohol; thereby minimizing the damage associated with alcohol consumption,”  writes Dr. Joseph Mercola. On his article “The Many Benefits of NAC — One of the Most Important Supplements You’ve Likely Never Heard Of”.

Conclusion

It remains controversial who should be taken glutathione. Some experts believe that people with diseases can benefit from a glutathione supplement. While others believe that people with poor nutrition need it most.

One thing is sure good nutrition, exercise and stress management is the fundamental of a healthy life. In case glutathione supplementation is needed, it is better to and more economical to supplement with cysteine and the other precursors.

Note:

Oral Glutathione supplements are highly expensive and not readily bioavailable.

Caution:

This article is not a diagnosis of any diseases but rather an informational tool to help readers.
